abstracts.cdata!:
This is a sectoral environmental
            assessment for the Georgia Forests Development Project,
            which aims to establish a sound forest management system.
            Mitigation measures focus on reforming laws, although
            environmental impacts are also discussed. Reforms will
            improve forest legislation by adding enforcement provisions,
            removing contradictions in overlapping laws, amending the
            tax and customs code, creating incentives for law
            enforcement agencies to implement sanctions for illegal
            actions, and issuing laws and regulations concerning
            environmental impact assessments and environmental permits.
            Direct action to protect forests include: incorporating the
            notions of multiple uses and prevailing functions in the
            Forest Code to avoid erosion and protect the soil and nearby
            water bodies, while allowing tourist and cultural uses of
            the forest; monitoring illegal cutting operations and
            imposing penalties; minimizing adverse impacts from road
            construction by using equipment and construction methods
            adapted to particular conditions; and stopping skidding
            operations during harvesting to avoid soil compaction and
            waterlogging. The construction of roads in remote areas will
            increase the pressure on hunted species. Biodiversity would
            be severely affected by forestry activities if they induce
            deforestation, but this eventuality is unlikely to take
            place in the Laboratory Zone.
